articles.headline: Google Shake-Up Is Effort to Revive Start-Up Spark
articles.snippet: Google said its co-founder, Larry Page, would take over as chief executive, replacing Eric E. Schmidt.
articles.abstract: Google said its co-founder, Larry Page, would take over as chief executive, replacing Eric E. Schmidt.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google made the biggest management shake-up in a decade on Thursday, handing the reins of the company to one of its co-founders in an effort to rediscover its start-up roots.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Volcker Rule May Work, Even if Vague
articles.snippet: The guidelines lay out no bright lines of right and wrong, but give regulators advice on where to look and what to look for.
articles.abstract: The guidelines lay out no bright lines of right and wrong, but give regulators advice on where to look and what to look for.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paul A. Volcker is a giant of financial history. He played a behind-the-scenes role when the United States abandoned the gold standard in 1971. He restored credibility to the Federal Reserve and slew inflation a decade later.

articles.headline: In Sperling, a Political Strategist Known for Getting It Done
articles.snippet: Gene Sperling was named director of the National Economic Council by President Obama because of his skill at political strategy.
articles.abstract: Gene Sperling was named director of the National Economic Council by President Obama because of his skill at political strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Weeks ago, President Obama told confidants that Gene Sperling, a counselor at the Treasury Department, was “indispensable.” Yet the president wrestled with whether to name him as the chief White House economic adviser, even knowing Mr. Sperling might leave if passed over.

articles.headline: A Short-Circuit to Distracted Driving
articles.snippet: Cell carriers are exploring technology aimed at reducing distractions by temporarily interrupting service.
articles.abstract: Cell carriers are exploring technology aimed at reducing distractions by temporarily interrupting service.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cellular carriers, having spent years trying to blanket the nation with phone service, are now working on ways to stop people from getting calls and texts when they are behind the wheel.

articles.headline: Banks Want Pieces of Fannie and Freddie’s Business
articles.snippet: Wells Fargo and other large banks want to become the new housing finance giants and bundle mortgages into securities. But they want an explicit government guarantee.
articles.abstract: Wells Fargo and other large banks want to become the new housing finance giants and bundle mortgages into securities. But they want an explicit government guarantee.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Obama administration prepares a report on the future of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, some of the nation’s largest banks are offering a few suggestions.

articles.headline: A Path Is Sought for States to Escape Their Debt Burdens
articles.snippet: Policy makers are working to find a way to let states declare bankruptcy and get out from under debts including the pensions they promised public workers.
articles.abstract: Policy makers are working to find a way to let states declare bankruptcy and get out from under debts including the pensions they promised public workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Policymakers are working behind the scenes to come up with a way to let states declare bankruptcy and get out from under crushing debts, including the pensions they have promised to retired public workers.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Bloc Presses Leaders to Slash Even More
articles.snippet: Conservatives want a cut in spending of at least $100 billion, compared with cuts in the current fiscal year of up to $80 billion being sought by party leaders.
articles.abstract: Conservatives want a cut in spending of at least $100 billion, compared with cuts in the current fiscal year of up to $80 billion being sought by party leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  House Republican leaders confronted pressure from conservatives on Thursday to take more aggressive steps to cut federal spending, with a large group of lawmakers calling for outlays to be slashed by $2.5 trillion over the next decade, far more than the party has sought so far.

articles.headline: Some See a Cash Motive in Duvalier’s Return
articles.snippet: Some say Jean-Claude Duvalier returned to Haiti to get around a new law that will make it harder for him to access millions frozen in Switzerland.
articles.abstract: Some say Jean-Claude Duvalier returned to Haiti to get around a new law that will make it harder for him to access millions frozen in Switzerland.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  When Jean-Claude Duvalier suddenly emerged from exile last weekend, saying he was here “to help” his devastated homeland, fears immediately spread across the country that the former dictator had come to stake a new claim to power.

articles.headline: Obama May Find Useless Regulations Are Scarcer Than Thought
articles.snippet: President Obama’s effort to weed out needless rules will probably find that regulations reviled by some are cherished by others, analysts say.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s effort to weed out needless rules will probably find that regulations reviled by some are cherished by others, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  There is a federal regulation that dictates that place names on new highway signs must be spelled with just one capital letter  like This, not THIS.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Edward Wyatt
